explanation:
For each symbol: 
- add_session_cookie: need its prototype/body to know whether it modifies the Session object or the MHD_Response object passed in. If it mutates session (or writes into response), session must be non-const; otherwise it could be const. This directly affects whether the session parameter should be const-qualified.
- MHD_add_response_header: need prototype/body to verify the const-qualification of the header-value parameter (mime) and whether the function ever mutates the string passed in. If it accepts/needs non-const char * or modifies the string, mime must be non-const; otherwise it could remain const.
- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static: need its prototype/body to confirm the buffer parameter is taken as const void * and whether the implementation ever modifies or takes ownership (frees) the buffer. If that function writes into or later frees the buffer, the buffer pointer passed in cannot safely be const; if it only reads/aliases it, const is appropriate.
- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls: this callee is invoked by the static creator; its behavior may determine whether the buffer is assumed modifiable/freed. We need it to understand ownership/mutation semantics of the created response with respect to the buffer pointer.
- MHD_queue_response: need prototype/body to determine whether it mutates the MHD_Connection object (connection) or the response object. If it modifies connection state, connection must be non-const; if it only reads, it might be const.
- MHD_destroy_response: need prototype/body to know whether destroying the response frees/modifies the underlying buffer pointed to by the response (thus affecting const correctness of the original buffer pointer). This affects whether the buffer passed to create_response must be mutable.
- struct Session: need the definition to see which fields might be modified by add_session_cookie (or other callees) so we can decide whether session parameter should be const.
- struct MHD_Connection: need the definition to determine whether MHD_queue_response (and related functions) mutate connection internals, informing whether connection must be non-const.
- struct MHD_Response: need its definition (and how it stores/owns the buffer pointer) to decide whether the response API mutates the buffer or takes ownership (frees it), which bears on whether the buffer pointer should be const.

Providing the above prototypes/definitions (or function implementations) lets the analyzer determine whether any pointer in serve_simple_form could be more const-qualified or must remain mutable per the MISRA rule (i.e., whether any callee writes through or takes ownership of the pointed object).
